G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as the property and events giving rise to this claim are located in Dorchester, within the territorial jurisdiction of the Boston Municipal Court, Dorchester Division.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as the property and events giving rise to this claim are located in Dorchester, within the territorial jurisdiction of the Boston Municipal Court, Dorchester Division.

Mass. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(3).proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(3) and G.L. c. 223, § 7, because the premises that are the subject of this dispute are located in Dorchester, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 7.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(3) and G.L. c. 223, § 7, because the premises that are the subject of this dispute are located in Dorchester, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: Defendant, as the landlord, had a duty under Massachusetts law to maintain the premises in habitable condition, including providing heat sufficient to meet the requirements of the State Sanitary Code, G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L, and 105 C.M.R. § 410.201, which requires that every dwelling be capable of maintaining a minimum temperature of 68 degrees Fahrenheit between 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m.

105 C.M.R. \u00a7 410.201.proposition: Defendant, as the landlord, had a duty under Massachusetts law to maintain the premises in habitable condition, including providing heat sufficient to meet the requirements of the State Sanitary Code, G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L, and 105 C.M.R. § 410.201, which requires that every dwelling be capable of maintaining a minimum temperature of 68 degrees Fahrenheit between 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Defendant, by failing to provide adequate and lawful heat levels, and by failing to make effective and lasting repairs after notice from Plaintiff, substantially interfered with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the Premises in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 99\u2013.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that inadequate heat, water, or other sanitary conditions can constitute a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g., Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 99–101 (1982); Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (1997); Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994); Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718 (1977); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 99\u2013.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely treats repeated flooding with water and sewage and the resulting unsanitary conditions as a violation of the tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the common-law covenant. The court repeatedly links Gem’s duty to maintain sanitary, watertight conditions (under the State Sanitary Code and warranty of habitability) with liability for “interfer[ing] with the quiet enjoyment” of the premises. This directly supports the broader proposition that inadequate sanitary conditions (here, flooding with water/sewage) can constitute a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 99\u2013.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 belongs to a body of statutes establishing tenants’ remedies against landlords who fail to provide safe and sanitary housing. … These statutes are designed to facilitate enforcement of State housing regulations and to provide relief for tenants deprived of decent homes. … The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent. See 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.500; Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443 (1979); Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973). The jury found … that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that inadequate heat, water, or other sanitary conditions can constitute a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g., Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 99–101 (1982); Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (1997); Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994); Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718 (1977); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.support_reasoning: The opinion in Al‑Ziab does interpret and apply the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does so in the context of lead‑paint liability and the need to show at least negligent conduct by the landlord. It does not discuss inadequate heat, water, or other sanitary conditions as violations of quiet enjoyment, nor does it state or reaffirm any rule specifically about such conditions. Using Al‑Ziab as authority for the specific proposition about heat, water, or sanitary conditions overreads the case’s holding.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.relevant_excerpt: "We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so)."

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that inadequate heat, water, or other sanitary conditions can constitute a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g., Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 99–101 (1982); Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (1997); Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994); Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718 (1977); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: This case concerns whether pervasive criminal/drug activity and the landlord’s failure to act can breach the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment; it does not address inadequate heat, water, or other sanitary/physical conditions. The court’s quiet enjoyment analysis focuses on security and third-party criminal activity, expressly distinguishing that from issues governed by the warranty of habitability and sanitary codes. Thus, it is not authority for the proposition that inadequate heat, water, or other sanitary conditions constitute a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that inadequate heat, water, or other sanitary conditions can constitute a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g., Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 99–101 (1982); Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (1997); Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994); Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718 (1977); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718.support_reasoning: Blackett v. Olanoff addresses constructive eviction and breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment based on excessive noise from a lounge the landlord permitted and could control. It does not involve inadequate heat, water, or sanitary conditions, nor does it discuss those types of conditions as constituting a violation of quiet enjoyment. Thus, while it is important Massachusetts authority on constructive eviction and quiet enjoyment, it does not support the specific proposition about inadequate heat, water, or sanitary conditions.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124, 127 (1959) (failure to supply light, heat, power, and elevator services).”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that inadequate heat, water, or other sanitary conditions can constitute a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g., Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 99–101 (1982); Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (1997); Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994); Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718 (1977); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season seriously impairs the character and value of the premises and “constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.” That is directly within the class of inadequate heat/sanitary conditions referenced in the proposition, and the court grounds this in both G.L. c. 186, § 14 and quiet enjoyment doctrine. Thus, Lowery is properly cited as authority that lack of heat can violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season (see State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.201, 410.750 [B] [1980]) seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See generally Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715-716 (1977), and cases cited.”

Hemingway v. Perini, 363 Mass. 180, 185\.proposition: It is not necessary for the landlord’s interference to be intentional; negligence or inaction after notice can be sufficient. Simon v. Solomon, supra; Hemingway v. Perini, 363 Mass. 180, 185–86 (1973).
Hemingway v. Perini, 363 Mass. 180, 185\.support_reasoning: The opinion is a negligence case against a utility for a defective light pole; it does not involve a landlord-tenant relationship, constructive eviction, or any rule about a landlord’s interference with a tenant’s use and enjoyment. Nowhere does the court discuss whether intent, negligence, or inaction after notice is sufficient to constitute wrongful interference by a landlord. Citing this case for that landlord-tenant proposition is therefore inaccurate and out of context.
Hemingway v. Perini, 363 Mass. 180, 185\.relevant_excerpt: "Edison installed and owned the pole. It had the duty to see that it was reasonably fit for use and had a continuing duty to inspect it and repair it when necessary... Hence, there was evidence from which the jury could properly infer that Edison was negligent in failing to discover and remedy the defect in the pole."

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127L.proposition: Defendant’s failure also violates the minimum habitability requirements of the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. § 410.201, as enforced under G.L. c. 111, § 127L, and such violations constitute evidence of a breach of quiet enjoyment. See Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 198–99 (1979).

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 198–99 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s failure also violates the minimum habitability requirements of the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. § 410.201, as enforced under G.L. c. 111, § 127L, and such violations constitute evidence of a breach of quiet enjoyment. See Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 198–99 (1979).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion does treat State Sanitary Code violations as the benchmark for habitability and explicitly notes that the landlord must at least comply with the State building and sanitary codes, but it does not involve or discuss G.L. c. 111, § 127L, nor does it frame sanitary code violations as evidence of a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Instead, the case is about breach of the implied warranty of habitability and rent abatement, not quiet enjoyment. Thus, citing Berman for the specific proposition that sanitary code violations under § 127L constitute evidence of a breach of quiet enjoyment overstates what the case holds.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In the latter instance, the landlord must comply at least with minimum standards prescribed by the State building and sanitary codes. Whether the scope of the warranty is broader is an open question. Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443, 451 (1979). … The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water. State Sanitary Code, Art. II, Regulations 5, 6 (1969) (current version at 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.190, 410.200, 410.201). The landlord can have no reasonable grounds to believe that noncompliance will be acceptable.”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. at 198–200
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: A landlord’s failure to provide functioning heat, where the tenant experiences ongoing discomfort or incurs extra expense to maintain a livable environment, amounts to constructive interference with quiet enjoyment. Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. at 198–200; Al-Ziab, 424 Mass. at 851.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6C.proposition: D. Awarding interest as provided by G.L. c. 231, § 6C; and

Mass. R. Civ. P. 54(d).proposition: C. Awarding reasonable costs pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14 and Mass. R. Civ. P. 54(d);
